I will encamp against you on all sides,
and I will lay siege against you with towers.
I will raise siege works against you.
29.4:
You will be brought so low
that you will speak from the ground.
You will murmur from the dust.
Your voice will be like a ghost from a pit in the ground,
and your speech will whisper from the dust.
29.5:
But your many foes will become like fine dust,
and the ruthless hordes like blowing chaff.
This will take place suddenly, in an instant.
29.6:
You will be visited by the Lord of Armies
with thunder, earthquake, and a loud noise,
with a strong wind and a storm,
and with the flames of a devouring fire.
29.7:
The hordes of nations that fight against Ariel,
all who fight against her and her stronghold,
all who besiege her—
all of them will be like a dream,
like a vision in the night.
29.8:
They will be like a hungry man who dreams and sees himself eating,
but then he wakes up, and his hunger is not satisfied.
They will be like a thirsty man who dreams and sees himself drinking,
but then he wakes up and, sure enough, he is weak with thirst.
That is how it will be with the hordes of nations
    that fight against Mount Zion.
29.9:
Be stunned! Be amazed!
Blind yourselves and be blind!
They are drunk, but not with wine.
They stagger, but not from beer.
29.10:
For the Lord has poured out a spirit of deep sleep over you.
He has closed your eyes—the prophets.
He has covered your heads—the seers.
29.11: For you this whole vision has become like the words of a sealed scroll. If you give it to someone who can read, and you say, “Read this, please,” he will say, “I can’t. It is sealed.”
29.12: And if you give it to someone who cannot read, and you say, “Read this, please,” he will say, “I can’t read.”
29.13:
The Lord says:
These people approach me with their words,
and they honor me with their lips,
but their hearts are far from me.
Their worship of me is nothing but commandments taught by men.
29.14:
So watch how I will continue to amaze these people
    with amazing, extraordinary things.
The wisdom of the wise will perish,
and the intelligence of the intelligent will be hidden.
29.15:
Woe to those who try to hide their plans from the Lord.
Their deeds are done in darkness,
and they think that no one sees them
or knows what they are doing.
29.16:
You turn things upside down!
Should the potter be treated like clay?
Should the thing that was made say to its maker,
    “You didn’t make me”?
Should the creation say to the creator,
    “You know nothing”?
29.17:
Isn’t it true that in a very short time
    Lebanon will be turned into a fertile field,
    and the fertile field will seem like a forest?
29.18:
On that day, the deaf will hear the words from a book,
and out of gloom and darkness the eyes of the blind will see.
29.19:
The humble will rejoice in the Lord once again,
and the poor will delight in the Holy One of Israel.
29.20:
But the ruthless will come to nothing.
Those who mock will be no more,
and all those who plan evil will be cut off—
29.21:
all those who slander others with a word,
all those who argue cases at the city gate,
all those who use false testimony to deprive the innocent of justice.
29.22:
Therefore this is what the Lord, who redeemed Abraham,
says about the house of Jacob:
    Jacob will not be ashamed anymore.
    His face will not grow pale.
29.23:
But when his children see what I do among them,
    they will honor my name.
    They will honor the Holy One of Jacob.
    They will stand in awe of the God of Israel.
29.24:
Those who are confused will come to understand,
    and those who complain will gladly receive instruction.

30.1:
Woe to this rebellious people, says the Lord.
They take advice, but not from me.
They establish an alliance, but not by my Spirit.
Then they sin more and more.
30.2:
Woe to those who go down to Egypt, without consulting me.
They seek Pharaoh’s protection,
and they take refuge in the shade of Egypt!
30.3:
So Pharaoh’s protection will bring you shame.
Taking refuge in the shade of Egypt will be your downfall.
30.4:
Even though Israel’s officials are in Zoan,
and their envoys have gone as far as Hanes,
30.5:
they will all be humiliated
because of a people that is useless to them.
They can neither help nor provide any benefit.
They bring only shame and reproach.
30.6:
An oracle about the animals of the Negev.
Through the land of trouble and distress,
the land of the lioness and the lion,
of the viper and the venomous flying serpent,
Judah’s envoys carry their wealth on the backs of donkeys
and their treasures on camels’ humps,
to a nation that cannot help them.
30.7:
For Egypt’s help is useless and serves no purpose.
That is why I have called her “the dragon that just sits there.”
30.8:
Go and write it on a tablet for them.
Record it on a scroll,
so that in the future it may serve as a permanent witness.
30.9:
These are a rebellious people, lying children,
children unwilling to hear the law of the Lord,
30.10:
who tell the seers, “Stop seeing!”
who tell the prophets, “Stop prophesying what is right!
Tell us pleasant things. Prophesy illusions.
30.11:
Leave the way! Turn from the path!
Stop getting in our face about the Holy One of Israel!”
30.12:
This is what the Holy One of Israel says:
    Since you have rejected my word,
    and you trust in oppression and deceit,
    and you rely on them,
30.13:
your guilt will be like a crack in a wall,
    bulging out and about to collapse.
    It will suddenly fall without warning.
30.14:
It will crash like a broken clay pot,
    smashed to pieces so violently that not one useful piece will be left,
    not even a piece good enough to pick up a coal from the hearth
    or to ladle water from a cistern.
30.15:
This is what the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel, says:
    If you repent and wait quietly, you will be saved.
    Your strength will depend on quietness and trust.
But you refused.
30.16:
You said, “No, we will flee on horseback!”
Yes indeed, you will flee.
You said, “We will ride away swiftly!”
Yes indeed, you will be pursued swiftly.
30.17:
A thousand will flee when just one threatens.
When five threaten, you will flee,
until you are like a single flag, fluttering on a mountaintop,
like a lonely banner on a hill.
30.18:
But the Lord is eager to be gracious to you.
He waits on high to have mercy on you,
for the Lord is a God of justice.
Blessed are all those who long for him.
30.19: So people will live in Zion. In Jerusalem you will weep no more. The Lord will be very gracious to you when he hears your cry. When he hears you, he will answer you.
30.20: Though the Lord has given you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, he is your teacher. He will not be hidden any longer. You will see your teacher with your own eyes.
30.21: Whenever you are tempted to turn to the right or to the left, you will hear his voice behind you, saying, “This is the way. Walk in it.”
30.22: You will defile your idols that are plated with silver and your images overlaid with gold. You will throw them away like a filthy cloth, saying, “Get away from me!”
30.23: Then he will give you rain so that you can sow seed in the ground. The bread from your land’s harvest will be excellent and plentiful. On that day your livestock will graze in wide pastures.
30.24: The oxen and the donkeys that work the ground will eat the best feed—winnowed with a shovel and a winnowing fork.
30.25:
On every lofty mountain and on every high hill there will be streams flowing with water.
It will be a day of terrible slaughter, when towers fall.
30.26: The light of the moon will be as bright as the sun, and the light of the sun will be seven times brighter—like the light of seven days—on the day when the Lord will bind up the wounds of his people and heal the injuries he inflicted.
30.27:
Look! The name of the Lord is coming from far away,
burning with anger, in a column of thick smoke.
His lips are full of anger,
and his tongue is a consuming fire.
30.28:
His breath is a stream at flood stage,
surging all the way up to your neck.
He shakes the nations in a sieve to destroy them,
and he puts a bridle in their mouths to lead them to destruction.
30.29:
You will sing as you do on the night of a holy festival,
    with glad hearts,
as when they go up with flutes to the mountain of the Lord,
to the Rock of Israel.
30.30:
The Lord will cause the majestic splendor of his voice to be heard.
He will make them see his arm come crashing down in fierce anger,
like the flames of a consuming fire,
like driving rain, a furious storm with hailstones.
30.31:
The voice of the Lord will terrify Assyria.
He will strike it with his rod.
30.32:
Every stroke of the punishing rod which the Lord will lay on them
    will be accompanied by the music of drums and lyres.
He himself will fight, battling them, swinging weapons.
30.33:
Topheth has long been made ready.
It is prepared for the king,
a flaming funeral pyre, deep and wide, with plenty of wood.
The breath of the Lord, like a river of liquid fire, sets it ablaze.

31.1:
Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help,
who put their faith in horses,
who trust in chariots because there are many of them,
who trust in charioteers because they are very powerful.
They do not trust in the Holy One of Israel.
They do not seek the Lord.
31.2:
The Lord is wise, and he will bring disaster.
He will not go back on his word,
but he will deal with those who do evil,
and with those who help the wicked.
31.3:
The Egyptians are merely men, not gods.
Their horses are flesh, not spirit.
When the Lord stretches out his hand to punish,
both the helper and the one seeking help will fall.
Together they will perish.
31.4:
This is what the Lord said to me:
    When a lion or a young lion snarls over its prey,
    and a band of shepherds is called out to drive it away,
    it is not afraid of their shouts,
    and it is not bothered by the noise they make.
    In the same way, the Lord of Armies will fearlessly come down
        to fight on Mount Zion and on its heights.
31.5:
Like a hovering bird,
the Lord of Armies will protect Jerusalem.
He will protect it and deliver it.
He will pass over it and preserve it.
31.6: O people of Israel, return to the one you have so completely betrayed.
31.7: In that day every one of you will throw away his idols of silver and his idols of gold—things you made, which caused you to sin.
31.8:
Assyria will fall, but not by a human sword.
A sword will devour him, but not one wielded by men.
He will flee from the sword,
but his young men will be forced into slavery.
31.9:
His rocky stronghold will pass away because of fear,
and his officials will abandon their banner in panic,
declares the Lord, whose fire is in Zion,
whose blast furnace is in Jerusalem.

32.1:
See, a king will reign in righteousness,
and officials will govern with justice.
32.2:
Each of them will be like a shelter from the wind
and a refuge from the storm,
like streams of water for a dry place,
like the shade of a massive cliff in a parched land.
32.3:
The eyes of those who see will not be closed,
and the ears of those who hear will listen.
32.4:
Hasty hearts will gain understanding,
and stammering tongues will speak clearly.
32.5:
The fool will no longer be called noble,
nor will rogues be treated like respectable people.
32.6:
The fool speaks folly,
and his heart plots evil:
to do what is ungodly,
to tell lies about the Lord,
to deny food to the hungry,
and to refuse even one drink for the thirsty.
32.7:
The rogue’s ways are evil.
He plots evil to ruin the humble with lies,
even when the poor speak with justice.
32.8:
But the noble man plans noble deeds,
and by noble deeds he stands.
32.9:
Get up, you complacent women, and listen!
You carefree girls, hear what I have to say!
32.10:
In a little more than a year, you carefree women will be worried,
because the grape harvest will fail,
and the fruit harvest will not arrive.
32.11:
Tremble, you complacent women!
Be worried, you carefree girls!
Strip yourselves naked,
and put sackcloth around your waist.
32.13:
because my people’s land will yield only thorns and briers.
Weep for all the houses where you partied,
    in the city where you celebrated.
32.14:
Then the fortress will be abandoned.
The crowded city will be deserted.
The citadel and the watchtower will become
    rugged ruins for a long time,
    enjoyed by wild donkeys,
    and a pasture for flocks,
32.15:
until the Spirit is poured out on us from on high,
and the wilderness becomes a fertile field,
and the fertile field seems like a forest.
32.16:
Then justice will dwell in the wilderness,
and righteousness will live in the fertile field.
32.17:
The result of righteousness will be peace,
and righteousness will bring lasting tranquility and security.
32.18:
My people will live in a peaceful place,
in secure dwellings,
and in quiet resting places.
32.19:
Even if hail destroys the forest,
or if the city is totally leveled,
32.20:
how blessed you will be,
as you sow seed beside streams,
and let your cattle and donkeys run free.

33.1:
Woe to you who destroy, even though you have not been destroyed,
you who betray, though you have not been betrayed!
When you have finished destroying, you will be destroyed,
and when you have finished betraying, you will be betrayed.
33.2:
O Lord, be gracious to us. We wait hopefully for you.
Be our strength every morning.
Be our salvation in times of trouble.
33.3:
At the thunder of your voice, people flee.
When you stir up your great power, nations scatter.
33.4:
Your plunder will be taken away
    the way a caterpillar eats things up.
People will swarm on it like a locust swarm.
33.5:
The Lord is exalted, because he dwells on high.
He will fill Zion with justice and righteousness.
33.6:
There will be stability in your time,
a wealth of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge.
Your treasure will be the fear of the Lord.
33.7:
Listen! Their elite troops are crying in the streets.
The peace envoys weep bitterly.
33.8:
The highways are deserted.
All travel has stopped.
The treaty has been broken.
Witnesses are despised,
and no one is respected.
33.9:
The land mourns and becomes weak.
Lebanon is ashamed and withers away.
The Plain of Sharon is like the Arabah,
and Bashan and Carmel are stripped bare.
33.10:
Now I will arise, says the Lord.
Now I will lift myself up.
Now I will be exalted.
33.11:
You will conceive chaff
and give birth to stubble.
Like fire, your own breath will consume you.
33.12:
People will be burned to lime,
like thorns that are cut and burned in the fire.
33.13:
You who are far away, recognize what I have done.
You who are close by, acknowledge my mighty acts.
33.14:
The sinners in Zion are afraid.
Trembling has seized the ungodly.
Who of us can live with a consuming fire?
Who of us can live in a place that burns without end?
33.15:
Those who walk righteously and speak blamelessly,
those who despise dishonest gain,
whose hands refuse a bribe,
whose ears will not listen to violent plans,
whose eyes reject evil—
33.16:
they will dwell on high.
Their defense will be a fortress on the cliffs.
Their bread will be provided.
    Their water supply will be reliable.
33.17:
Your eyes will see the King in his splendor.
They will see a land that stretches far and wide.
33.18:
Your heart will think about the past terrors.
You will think, “Where is the one who took the inventory?
Where is the one who weighed the silver?
Where is the one who counted the towers?”
33.19:
You will no longer see a barbaric people,
a people with unintelligible speech, which you cannot understand,
a people who babble in a language that makes no sense.
33.20:
Look at Zion, the city where we hold our festivals.
You will see Jerusalem as a peaceful place,
as a tent that cannot be removed.
Its stakes will never be pulled up.
Its ropes will never be broken.
33.21:
There the Lord will be with us in majesty,
as in a place with wide rivers and streams,
where no enemy warship can row,
where no sailing ship can slip past.
33.22:
Because the Lord is our judge,
the Lord is our lawgiver,
and the Lord is our king,
he is the one who will save us.
33.23:
Your rigging hangs loose.
The mast is not steady.
The sail is not set.
When they divide all the plunder,
there will be so much that even the crippled will take part.
33.24:
No one who lives there will say, “I am sick.”
The guilt of the people who live there will be forgiven.

34.1:
Come near, you nations, and hear!
Listen, you peoples.
Let the earth and everything in it hear,
the world and everything that it produces.
34.2:
The Lord is angry with all the nations,
and he is furious with all their armies.
He has condemned them to destruction.
He has handed them over for slaughter.
34.3:
Their fallen bodies will lie unburied,
and the stench of their corpses will linger.
The mountains will flow with their blood.
34.4:
The whole army of the heavens will fall apart.
The sky will be rolled up like a scroll,
and its whole army will waste away and fall,
    like leaves withering on a vine,
    like fruit that falls from a fig tree.
34.5:
Yes, my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens.
Now it will fall on Edom,
on the people I have sentenced to judgment.
34.6:
The sword of the Lord is covered with blood.
It is coated with fat,
with the blood of lambs and goats,
with the fat from the kidneys of rams,
for the Lord has made a sacrifice in Bozrah,
a massive slaughter in the land of Edom.
34.7:
Wild oxen will fall along with them,
bull calves and powerful bulls.
Their land will be soaked with blood,
and their dust will be saturated with fat.
34.8:
It will be a day of vengeance for the Lord,
a year of retribution for Zion’s sake.
34.9:
Edom’s streams will be turned into pitch,
its dust into sulfur,
and its land will become burning pitch,
34.10:
which will not be extinguished night or day.
Its smoke will go up forever.
Generation after generation, it will lie in ruins.
No one will ever pass through it. Never again!
34.11:
But the desert owl and the porcupine will live there.
The screech owl and the raven will nest there.
God will stretch a measuring line for chaos over Edom,
and a plumb line for uninhabited ruins.
34.12:
There will be nothing left for its nobles to call a kingdom.
All its officials will be gone.
34.13:
Thorns will cover its citadels.
Thistles and briers will overgrow its fortresses.
It will be a den of jackals,
a haunt for ostriches.
34.14:
Desert animals and hyenas will gather,
and wild goats will bleat to each other.
Creatures of the night will settle there
and find a resting place.
34.15:
An owl will nest there.
She will lay eggs, hatch them,
and gather her young under her shade.
Falcons will gather there too,
each with its mate.
34.16:
Search through the book of the Lord, and read.
Not one of them will be missing.
Not one will lack her mate.
For his mouth has commanded this,
and his Spirit has gathered them together.
34.17:
He has allotted this land for these creatures.
His hand has divided it up for them with a surveying line.
They will possess it forever.
They will live there generation after generation.

35.1:
The wilderness and the desert will be glad.
The wasteland of the Arabah will rejoice and blossom like a crocus.
35.2:
It will bloom lavishly,
and there will be great joy and singing.
The glory of Lebanon will be given to it.
It will be excellent like Carmel and Sharon.
They will see the glory of the Lord,
the majesty of our God.
35.3:
Strengthen the weak hands,
and make the shaky knees steady.
35.4:
Tell those who have a fearful heart:
    Be strong.
    Do not be afraid.
    Look! Your God will come with vengeance.
    With God’s own retribution, he will come and save you.
35.5:
Then the eyes of the blind will be opened,
and the ears of the deaf will be unplugged.
35.6:
The crippled will leap like a deer,
and the tongue of the mute will sing for joy.
Waters will flow in the wilderness,
and streams in the wasteland.
35.7:
The burning sand will become a pool,
and in the thirsty ground there will be springs of water.
There will be grass, reeds, and rushes where the haunts
    of jackals once lay.
35.8:
A highway will be there,
a road that will be called the holy way.
The impure will not walk there.
It will be reserved for those who walk in that holy way.
Wicked fools will not wander onto it.
35.9:
No lion will be there,
nor will any ferocious animal go up on it.
They will not be found there,
but only the redeemed will walk there.
35.10:
Then those ransomed by the Lord will return.
They will enter Zion with a joyful shout,
and everlasting joy will crown their heads.
Happiness and joy will overtake them,
and sorrow and sighing will flee away.

36.1: Now in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all of the fortified cities of Judah and seized them.
36.2: The king of Assyria sent his herald from Lachish to Jerusalem to King Hezekiah. A large army was with him. He stood by the water channel from the upper pool on the road to the launderer’s field.
36.3: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was the palace administrator, Shebna, who was the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, who was the recorder, came out to meet him.
36.4:
The herald told them this.
Tell Hezekiah this is what the Great King, the king of Assyria, says.
What makes you so confident?
36.5: Your wisdom and military strength are based on empty promises. Who do you trust, so that you now have rebelled against me?
36.6: Tell me! Are you really trusting in Egypt to be your staff, that splintered reed that will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it? That is what happens to anyone who relies on Pharaoh king of Egypt.
36.7: If you say to me that you trust in the Lord your God, isn’t he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed? Didn’t Hezekiah tell Judah and Jerusalem to worship at this altar?
36.8: Now then, make a bargain with my master the king of Assyria. I will give you two thousand horses, if you can find enough riders for them.
36.9: How can you resist even one officer from among the least of my lord’s servants? How can you put your trust in Egypt for chariots and charioteers?
36.10: What’s more, have I attacked this land to destroy it without the Lord’s orders? The Lord is the one who said to me, “Go up against this land and destroy it.”
36.11: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the herald, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, because we understand it. Do not speak to us in Hebrew, because there are people on the city wall who are listening.”
36.12: But the herald replied, “Has my lord sent me only to you and to your lord to speak these words, and not to the men who are sitting on the wall, who will eat their own excrement and drink their own urine with you?”
36.13:
Then the herald stood up and called out in a loud voice in Hebrew. He said:
Listen to the words of the Great King, the king of Assyria!
36.14:
This is what the king says.
Do not let Hezekiah deceive you! He will not be able to deliver you.
36.15: Do not let Hezekiah persuade you to trust in the Lord, when he says that the Lord will save you, and that this city will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.
36.16: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for this is what the king of Assyria says. Make a peace treaty with me and surrender to me. Each one of you will eat from his own vine, from his own fig tree, and each one of you will drink water from his own cistern,
36.17: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land with grain and sweet wine, a land with bread and vineyards.
36.18:
Do not let Hezekiah make you think that the Lord will deliver you!
Have any of the gods of the nations kept them from being handed over to the king of Assyria?
36.19: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my hand?
36.20: Which of the gods of these countries have delivered their country from my hand? Will the Lord really deliver Jerusalem from my hand?
36.21: But the officials remained silent, saying nothing in reply, because the king had commanded, “Do not answer him.”
36.22: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was the palace administrator, Shebna, who was the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, who was the recorder, went to Hezekiah with their clothing torn and told him everything the herald had said.

37.1: When King Hezekiah heard the report, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and went into the House of the Lord.
37.2: He sent Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, who were wearing sackcloth, to Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz.
37.3: They told him what Hezekiah said: “This is a day of distress, rebuke, and humiliation, because children are about to be born, but there is no strength left to give birth.
37.4: Perhaps the Lord your God will take note of the words of this herald, who was sent by his lord, the king of Assyria, in defiance of the living God, and perhaps the Lord your God will rebuke him for what he has heard. So please, pray for the small group that is left here.”
37.5: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,
37.6: he said to them, “Tell your master that this is what the Lord says. Do not be afraid of what you have heard. The lackeys of the king of Assyria have blasphemed against me.
37.7: Watch! I will put a spirit in him, so that when he hears certain news, he will return to his own land. There I will cause him to be killed.”
37.8: Then the herald went back. He heard that the king of Assyria had already left Lachish and was fighting against Libnah.
37.9: When Sennacherib heard that Tirhakah king of Cush had set out to fight against him, he sent messengers to Hezekiah
37.10:
to say this to Hezekiah king of Judah:
Do not let the God you trust deceive you, saying that Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.
37.11: Listen, you yourself have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other lands, destroying them completely. And you expect to be saved?
37.12: Did the gods of the nations whom my fathers destroyed save them—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden, who were in Tel Assar?
37.13: Where is the king of Hamath, and the king of Arpad, and the kings of the cities of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?
37.14: Hezekiah took the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it. He went up to the House of the Lord and placed it there before the Lord.
37.15: Then he prayed to the Lord.
37.16: O Lord of Armies, God of Israel, seated above the cherubim, you alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.
37.17: Turn your ear toward me, Lord, and hear. Open your eyes, Lord, and see. Listen to all of the words of Sennacherib, who has defied the living God.
37.18: It is true, Lord, that the kings of Assyria have destroyed all these lands and their territory.
37.19: They have thrown their gods into the fire, for they were not gods at all, but the work of human hands, wood and stone. So they have destroyed them.
37.20: Now, Lord our God, save us from his power, and let all the kingdoms of the earth know that you are the Lord, and you alone.
37.21:
Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent word to Hezekiah.
The Lord, the God of Israel, says that because you have prayed to him about Sennacherib king of Assyria,
37.22:
the Lord sends you this reply about him.
The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and jeers at you.
The daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head at you in scorn.
37.23:
Who is it whom you have mocked and blasphemed?
Against whom have you raised your voice
and lifted up your proud eyes?
It is against the Holy One of Israel.
37.24:
You have used your servants to mock the Lord.
You have boasted, “I have driven my many chariots
up the high mountains, to the most remote parts of Lebanon.
I cut down its tallest cedars and its best fir trees.
I have reached its highest peak, its most lush forest.
37.25:
I dug wells and drank their water,
and I dried up all the rivers of Egypt with the soles of my feet.”
37.26:
Have you not heard?
I did all this long ago.
I formed all this in ancient times.
Now I caused it all to take place.
I enabled you to destroy fortified cities,
reducing them to heaps of ruins.
37.27:
Their inhabitants were powerless.
Overwhelmed and ashamed,
they were like plants in the field,
like fresh green grass, like grass on a housetop,
and like a field before it has grown.
37.28:
But I know when you stand and when you sit,
when you go out and when you come in,
and how you rage wildly against me.
37.29:
Because you rage against me,
and because your arrogance has reached my ears,
I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth,
and I will make you go back by the same way that you came.
37.30:
This will be a sign for you:
This year you will eat what grows by itself.
Next year you will eat what springs up from that.
But in the third year, you will sow crops and harvest them.
You will plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
37.31:
The surviving remnant of the house of Judah
will again put down roots below and bear fruit above.
37.32:
For from Jerusalem a remnant will go out,
and survivors from Mount Zion.
The zeal of the Lord of Armies will accomplish this.
37.33:
This is what the Lord says about the king of Assyria:
He will not enter this city.
He will not shoot an arrow there.
He will not advance against it with a shield,
and he will not build a siege ramp against it.
37.34:
He will go back by the same route that he came,
and he will not enter this city, declares the Lord.
37.36: Then an angel of the Lord went and struck down one hundred eighty-five thousand men in the Assyrian camp. Early in the morning, there they were—all the dead bodies.
37.37: Then Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and left. He returned to Nineveh and remained there.
37.38: One day when Sennacherib was worshipping in the house of his god Nisrok, his sons Adrammelek and Sharezer struck him down with the sword. They fled to the land of Ararat, and his son Esarhaddon became king in his place.

38.1: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was dying. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him and said, “This is what the Lord says. Give instructions to your household, because you are going to die. You will not survive.”
38.2: So Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord.
38.3: He said, “Please remember, Lord, how I have walked before you in truth and with my whole heart. I have done what is good in your eyes.” Hezekiah wept bitterly.
38.4: Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah.
38.5:
Go back and tell Hezekiah that this is what the Lord, the God of your father David, says:
I have heard your prayer and I have seen your tears. Now then, I will add fifteen years to your life.
38.6: I will rescue you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria. I will defend this city.
38.7: This will be the sign from the Lord to you. The Lord will do what he has promised.
38.8:
Watch! I will make the shadow of the setting sun that has moved down the stairway of Ahaz move back, ten steps higher on the staircase.
Then the sun’s shadow moved backwards, ten steps higher on the stairway that it had just descended.
38.9: A poem written by Hezekiah king of Judah, after his illness and recovery.
38.10:
I thought that, only halfway through my life,
I was entering into the gates of death,
deprived of the remaining years of my life.
38.11:
I thought, I will not see the Lord—
the Lord in the land of the living.
I will no longer see anyone among the inhabitants of the world.
38.12:
My dwelling place is being pulled down.
It is carried away from me like a shepherd’s tent.
I have rolled up my life like a weaver.
He is cutting me off from the loom.
From day until night, you make an end of me.
38.13:
I pondered this until the morning.
He will break all my bones like a lion!
From day until night, you make an end of me.
38.14:
I chirp weakly like a swift or a swallow.
I mourn like a dove.
My eyes are tired from looking upward.
O Lord, I am oppressed.
Be my security.
38.15:
What can I say?
He has spoken to me, and he is the one to act.
I will march slowly throughout all my years,
because my heart is bitter.
38.16:
Lord, people live because you give them life.
My spirit lives through this.
Restore me, and let me live.
38.17:
The bitter things I experienced were for my benefit.
Your love has preserved my life from the pit of destruction,
for you have thrown all my sins behind your back.
38.18:
The grave cannot thank you.
Death cannot praise you.
Those who go down into the pit cannot trust your faithfulness.
38.19:
The living one, the living one, he praises you, as I do today.
A father tells his children about your faithfulness.
38.20:
The Lord will save me,
so we will sing songs with stringed instruments
    all the days of our lives in the House of the Lord.
38.21: Isaiah had said, “Have them take a cake of figs, apply it as a poultice on the inflamed spot, and he will recover.”
38.22: Hezekiah had also asked, “What will be the sign that I will go up to the House of the Lord?”

39.1: At that time, Merodak Baladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, because he had heard that Hezekiah had been sick and had recovered.
39.2: Hezekiah was happy to receive the envoys, and he showed them his palace treasury—the silver and the gold, the spices and the precious oil, his whole armory, and everything that was found in his treasuries. There was nothing in his palace or in all his domain that Hezekiah did not show them.
39.3:
Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and asked him, “What did those men say? Where did they come from?”
Hezekiah replied, “They have come from a faraway country, from Babylon.”
39.4:
The prophet asked, “What did they see in your palace?”
Hezekiah said, “They have seen everything in my palace. There is nothing among my treasures that I did not show them.”
39.5: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Listen to the word of the Lord of Armies.
39.6: Listen carefully. The days are coming when whatever is in your house—everything that your fathers have stored up until today—will be carried away to Babylon. Not a thing will be left, says the Lord.
39.7: They will take away some of the sons who were born to you, your own children, and they will become eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
39.8: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord which you have spoken is good.” For Hezekiah also said, “There will be peace and stability during my days.”

40.1: Comfort, comfort my people, says your God.
40.2:
Speak to the heart of Jerusalem and call out to her.
Her warfare really is over.
Her guilt is fully paid for.
Yes, she has received from the Lord’s hand double for all her sins.
40.3:
A voice is calling out:
In the wilderness prepare the way for the Lord.
In the wasteland make a level highway for our God.
40.4:
Every valley will be raised up,
and every mountain and hill will be made low.
The rugged ground will become level,
and the rough places will become a plain.
40.5:
Then the glory of the Lord will be revealed,
and all flesh together will see it.
    Yes, the mouth of the Lord has spoken.
40.6:
A voice was saying, “Cry out!”
And I said, “What shall I cry out?”
    All flesh is grass,
    and all its beauty is like a wildflower in the countryside.
40.7:
Grass withers, flowers fade,
    when the breath of the Lord blows on them.
    Yes, the people are grass.
40.8:
Grass withers, flowers fade,
    but the Word of our God endures forever.
40.9:
Get up on a high mountain,
O Zion, you herald of good news.
Lift up your voice with strength,
O Jerusalem, you herald of good news.
Lift it up! Do not be afraid!
Say to the cities of Judah,
“Here is your God!”
40.10:
Look, God the Lord will come with strength,
and his arm is ruling for him.
Look, his reward is with him.
The result of his work is in front of him.
40.11:
Like a shepherd he will care for his flock.
With his arm he will gather the lambs.
He will lift them up on his lap.
He will gently lead the nursing mothers.
40.12:
Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand?
Who marked off the heavens with the width of his hand?
Who scooped up the dust of the earth with a measuring cup?
Who weighed the mountains with a balance
and the hills with scales?
40.13:
Who has directed the Spirit of the Lord?
Who can teach him anything or serve as his advisor?
40.14:
Who was his advisor to give him insight?
Who taught him the path of justice?
Who taught him knowledge?
Who showed him the way to complete understanding?
40.15:
Indeed, nations are like a drop in a bucket,
and they are treated like powder on a scale.
Look, he lifts up islands like dust!
40.16:
Not even the forests of Lebanon could provide enough wood to burn,
and its animals are not enough for a whole burnt offering.
40.17:
All the nations are nothing to him.
By him they are regarded as worthless,
as less than nothing.
40.18:
So to whom will you compare God?
What image can you compare to him?
40.19:
A craftsman casts the idol,
and a goldsmith overlays it with gold.
He forges silver chains for it.
40.20:
He chooses mulberry wood as an offering,
wood that will not rot.
He looks for a skillful craftsman
    to erect an idol that will not fall over.
40.21:
Do you not know? Have you not heard?
Has it not been declared to you from the beginning?
Have you not understood it from the founding of the earth?
40.22:
He is the one who sits above the circle of the earth.
To him its inhabitants are like grasshoppers.
He stretches out the heavens like a curtain,
and he spreads them out like a tent to live in.
40.23:
He is the one who reduces dignitaries to nothing.
He makes the judges of the world useless.
40.24:
They have hardly been planted.
They have hardly been sown.
Their stem has hardly taken root in the earth.
Then he blows on them, and they dry up.
A driving storm carries them away like chaff.
40.25:
To whom can you compare me as if we were equals?
says the Holy One.
40.26:
Lift up your eyes to the heavens,
and see who created these things.
See who brings out their army in great number
and calls them all by name.
Because of his great strength and mighty power,
not one of them is missing.
40.27:
Why do you speak, O Jacob?
O Israel, why do you say,
“My way is hidden from the Lord,
and justice for me is ignored by my God”?
40.28:
Do you not know? Have you not heard?
The Lord is the eternal God.
He is the Creator of the ends of the earth.
He will not grow tired, and he will not become weary.
No one can find a limit to his understanding.
40.29:
He is the one who gives strength to the weak,
and he increases the strength of those who lack power.
40.30:
Young men grow tired and become weary.
Even strong men stumble and fall.
40.31:
But those who wait for the Lord will receive new strength.
They will lift up their wings and soar like eagles.
They will run and not become weary.
They will walk and not become tired.

41.1:
Prepare to present your case to me, you coastlands,
and let the peoples renew their strength.
Let them come near. Yes, let them say,
“We will gather together for the verdict.”
41.2:
Who has aroused this one from the east?
In righteousness he summons him to his feet.
He gives nations to him
and causes him to rule over kings.
He makes them like dust with his sword,
like wind-driven stubble with his bow.
41.3:
He pursues them and passes by safely.
His feet do not touch the ground.
41.4:
Who accomplished this and carried it out
by summoning generations from the beginning?
I, the Lord, am the first,
and at the very end I will still be the one.
41.5:
The coastlands see and fear.
The ends of the earth tremble.
They draw near. They come.
41.6:
Each one assists his neighbor,
and to his brother he says, “Be strong.”
41.7:
The craftsman strengthens the refiner.
The one who flattens with the hammer
    strengthens the one who strikes the anvil.
Concerning the soldering he says, “It is good.”
He fastens it with nails so that it cannot be moved.
41.8:
But you, O Israel, my servant,
O Jacob, whom I have chosen,
the offspring of Abraham, whom I love,
41.9:
whom I have snatched from the ends of the earth,
whom I have called from its corners—
I have said to you, “You are my servant.”
I have chosen you and not rejected you.
41.10:
Do not fear, for I am with you.
Do not be overwhelmed, for I am your God.
I will strengthen you. Yes, I will help you.
I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.
41.11:
Just watch, they will be ashamed and humiliated—
all those who are angry with you.
They will become nothing and perish—
those men who oppose you.
41.12:
You will look for them, but you will not find them—
those men who contend against you.
They will become absolutely nothing, less than nothing—
those men who battle against you.
41.13:
For I am the Lord your God.
I am the one who is holding on to your right hand.
I am the one who says to you, “Do not fear. I myself am helping you.”
41.14:
Do not fear, you worm, Jacob, you few men of Israel.
I myself am helping you, declares the Lord,
your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.
41.15:
Look, I am making you into a sharp, new threshing sledge
    with double-edged blades.
You will thresh mountains and crush them.
You will turn hills into chaff.
41.16:
You will winnow them,
and a wind will lift them up.
A strong wind will scatter them.
But you, you will rejoice in the Lord.
In the Holy One of Israel you will be confident.
41.17:
The afflicted and the poor seek water, but there is none.
Their tongues are parched with thirst.
I, the Lord, I myself will answer them.
I, the God of Israel, will not leave them.
41.18:
I will open rivers on the barren heights.
In the middle of valleys there will be springs.
I will turn the wilderness into a pool of water,
and the dry land will pour out water.
41.19:
In the wilderness I will place cedar, acacia, myrtle, and olive trees.
In the wasteland I will plant fir, maple, and pines together,
41.20:
so that they may see and know,
and pay attention and perceive this all together,
    that the hand of the Lord has done this,
    and the Holy One of Israel has created it.
41.21:
“Present your case,” says the Lord.
“Set forth your strongest points,” says the King of Jacob.
41.22:
Let them present and declare to us what is going to occur.
What were the first things you predicted?
Tell us, so that we can ponder them,
so that we can know their outcome.
Or, announce to us the coming things.
41.23:
Declare to us the things that are still coming in the distant future.
Then we will know that you are gods.
In fact, just do something, do anything—good or evil,
so that we may be overwhelmed and terrified together.
41.24:
Look, you are less than nothing,
and your work is less than zero.
Anyone who chooses you is detestable.
41.25:
I have stirred up someone from the north,
and he is coming from the rising of the sun.
He will call upon my name.
He will walk over rulers as if they were mud,
the way a potter tramples clay.
41.26:
Who declared this from the beginning so that we could know it,
and ahead of time so that we could say, “He is right”?
In fact, not one of them declares this.
In fact, not one of them makes this known.
In fact, no one hears you say anything.
41.27:
I was first to announce to Zion, “Look, here they are,”
and I sent a herald of good news to Jerusalem.
41.28:
When I looked, there was no one.
None of them could give advice,
even when I kept asking them to respond.
41.29:
Look, all of them are useless.
Their works are nothing.
Their images are empty wind.

42.1:
Here is my servant, whom I uphold,
my chosen one in whom I delight.
I am placing my Spirit on him.
He will announce a just verdict for the nations.
42.2:
He will not cry out.
He will not raise his voice.
He will not make his voice heard in the street.
42.3:
A bent reed he will not break,
and a dimly burning wick he will not snuff out.
He will faithfully bring forth a just verdict.
42.4:
He will not burn out, and he will not be broken
until he establishes justice on the earth.
The coastlands will wait for his law.
42.5:
This is what the true God says,
the Lord who creates the heavens and stretches them out,
who spreads out the earth
and everything that it produces,
who gives breath to the people on it
and life to those who walk on it.
42.6:
I am the Lord.
    I have called you in righteousness.
    I will hold on to your hand,
    and I will guard you.
    I will appoint you to be a covenant for the people,
    to be a light for the nations,
42.7:
to open the eyes of the blind,
    to bring the prisoners out from the dungeon,
    and to bring those who sit in darkness out of prison.
42.8:
I am the Lord; that is my name.
    I will not give my glory to another,
    nor my praise to idols.
42.9:
Look, the former things have taken place,
    and I am declaring new things.
    I am making them known to you before they spring forth.
42.10:
Sing to the Lord a new song.
Sing his praise from the end of the earth,
you people who go down to the sea
    and everything that fills it,
you coastlands and those who inhabit them.
42.11:
Let the wilderness and its towns lift up their voice,
along with the settlements where Kedar lives.
Let the inhabitants of Sela sing for joy.
Let them shout from the mountain tops.
42.12:
Let them give glory to the Lord,
and let them declare his praise among the coastlands.
42.13:
The Lord will set out like a hero.
Like a warrior, he will work himself into a frenzy.
He will shout. Yes, he will raise a war cry.
He will be heroic against his enemies.
42.14:
I have been silent for a long time.
I have kept still. I have restrained myself.
But now, like a woman giving birth, I will scream.
I will gasp and pant.
42.15:
I will dry up mountains and hills.
I will make all their grass wither.
I will turn rivers into islands.
I will dry up pools.
42.16:
I will lead the blind on a way they do not know.
Along paths they do not know I will direct them.
Ahead of them I will turn darkness into light
and rough places into level ground.
These are the things I will accomplish for them.
I will not abandon them.
42.17:
They will be turned back and completely disgraced—
those who trust in an idol,
those who say to molten images, “You are our gods.”
42.18:
You deaf ones, listen!
You blind ones, watch carefully so that you can see!
42.19:
Who is as blind as my servant?
Who is as deaf as my messenger whom I sent?
Who is as blind as my associate,
as blind as the servant of the Lord?
42.20:
You, Israel, see many things, but you do not observe.
Israel opens his ears, but he does not hear.
42.21:
Because of his own righteousness,
the Lord was pleased to make his law great and glorious.
42.22:
But this is a people plundered and looted.
All of them are trapped in holes,
and they are hidden in prisons.
They have become plunder, and there is no rescuer.
They have become loot and no one says, “Give it back!”
42.23:
Who among you will turn his ear toward this?
Who will pay attention and listen for the future?
42.24:
Who gave up Jacob to looters
and Israel to plunderers?
Was it not the Lord, against whom we sinned?
But they were not willing to walk in his ways,
and they did not listen to his law.
42.25:
So he poured out wrath on them,
his anger, and the violence of battle.
It set them on fire all around, but they did not understand.
It burned in them, but they did not take it to heart.

43.1:
But now this is what the Lord says,
the Lord who created you, O Jacob,
the Lord who formed you, O Israel.
    Do not be afraid, because I have redeemed you.
    I have called you by name. You are mine.
43.2:
When you cross through the waters, I will be with you.
    When you cross the rivers, they will not sweep you away.
    When you walk through fire, you will not be burned,
    and the flame will not set you on fire.
43.3:
Because I am the Lord your God,
    the Holy One of Israel, your Savior,
    I gave Egypt as your ransom,
    Cush and Seba in exchange for you.
43.4:
Because you are precious and honored in my eyes,
    and I myself love you,
    I will give people in exchange for you,
    and peoples in exchange for your life.
43.5:
Do not be afraid, because I am with you.
    From the east I will bring your offspring,
    and from the west I will gather you.
43.6:
I will say to the north, “Give them back!”
    and to the south, “Do not hold them.”
    Bring my sons from far away
    and my daughters from the end of the earth—
43.7:
everyone who is called by my name,
    everyone I created for my glory,
    everyone I formed,
    yes, everyone I have made.
43.8:
Bring out the people who are blind, though they have eyes,
    and the people who are deaf, though they have ears.
43.9:
Let all the nations be gathered together,
    and let peoples be assembled.
    Who among them has declared this?
    Who has made known to us the former things?
    Let them produce their witnesses to show that they were right,
    so that people can hear and say, “This is truth.”
43.10:
You are my witnesses, declares the Lord.
    You are my servant, whom I have chosen,
    so that you may know me and believe in me,
    so that you will understand that I am he.
    Before me no god was formed,
    and after me there will not be another.
43.11:
I, yes I, am the Lord,
    and apart from me there is no savior.
43.12:
I myself declared it.
    I brought salvation, and I announced it.
    It was not some strange god among you.
    You are my witnesses, declares the Lord,
    and I am God.
43.13:
Indeed, from the first day, I am he.
    There is no one who can deliver anyone from my hand.
    I act, and who can reverse it?
43.14:
This is what the Lord says,
    the Lord your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.
    For your sake I am taking action against Babylon,
    and I will bring down all the Chaldeans as refugees,
        in the ships over which they rejoiced.
43.15:
I am the Lord, your Holy One,
    Israel’s Creator, your King.
43.16:
This is what the Lord says,
    who makes a road through the sea
    and a path through mighty waters,
43.17:
who brings out the chariot and the horses,
    the army and the strong warrior.
    They will all lie down together.
    They will not get up.
    They are extinguished.
    Like a wick they go out.
43.18:
Do not remember the former things.
    Do not keep thinking about ancient things.
43.19:
Watch, I am about to do a new thing.
    Now it will spring up. Don’t you know about it?
    Indeed I will make a road in the wilderness.
    In the wasteland I will make rivers.
43.20:
The wild animals, the jackals and ostriches, will honor me,
    because I am providing water in the wilderness,
    rivers in a parched wasteland,
    water for my chosen people to drink.
43.21: This people that I formed for myself will declare my praise.
43.22:
But you have not called on me, O Jacob.
    Instead, you have become weary of me, O Israel.
43.23:
You have not brought me sheep as your whole burnt offerings.
    You did not glorify me with your sacrifices.
    I did not make you serve me with a grain offering.
    I did not make you weary with demands for incense.
43.24:
You did not purchase fragrant cane for me with silver
    or satisfy me with the fat from your sacrifices.
    Instead you have made me serve because of your sins.
    You have made me weary because of your guilt.
43.25:
I, yes I, am he.
    I blot out your rebellious deeds for my own sake,
    and I will not remember your sins.
43.26:
Refresh my memory.
    Let us review your case together.
    Present your defense so that you may be acquitted.
43.27:
Your first father sinned,
    and your mediators rebelled against me.
43.28:
Therefore I am repudiating the officials of the sanctuary,
    and I am giving Jacob over to complete destruction
    and Israel to insults.

44.1:
But now listen, O Jacob my servant,
O Israel, whom I have chosen.
44.2:
This is what the Lord, your Maker, says,
the Lord who formed you from the womb, who will help you.
    Do not be afraid, my servant Jacob,
    Jeshurun, whom I have chosen,
44.3:
because I will pour out water upon a thirsty land,
    and streams of water upon dry ground.
    I will pour out my Spirit on your offspring,
    and my blessing on your descendants.
44.4:
They will spring up like a tree in a grassy meadow,
    like willows beside flowing streams.
44.5:
One person will say, “I belong to the Lord.”
    Another will be called by the name of Jacob.
    Another will write on his hand, “Belonging to the Lord,”
    and he will take the name of Israel.
44.6:
This is what the Lord, the King of Israel,
Israel’s Redeemer, the Lord of Armies, says.
    I am the first, and I am the last.
    Except for me, there is no god.
44.7:
For who is like me? Let him declare it.
    Let him recite in order for me the things that took place
        since the time I established an ancient people.
    Or let them declare what is yet to come,
    and what is going to take place.
44.8:
Do not tremble, and do not be frightened.
    Did I not announce this to you,
    and declare it already long ago?
    You are my witnesses.
    Is there any god except me?
    There is no other Rock. I am not aware of any other.
44.9:
All those who form an idol are good for nothing.
    All the things which delight them provide no benefit.
    As for their witnesses—they do not see.
    They know nothing, so they will be ashamed.
44.10: Who is this who forms a god or casts a metal image that can provide no profit?
44.11: Look at him! All his associates will be ashamed. The craftsmen are merely men. Let them all gather themselves and take a stand. They will be terrified and ashamed together.
44.12: A blacksmith uses a cutting tool and makes an idol over hot coals. With hammers he shapes it. He makes it with his strong arm, but he becomes hungry and has no strength left. He does not drink water, and so he grows faint.
44.13: A woodworker stretches out a measuring line. He marks the lines with a stylus. He shapes the idol with chisels. He marks it with a compass. Then he carves it till it is shaped like a person, like a splendid man to inhabit a shrine.
44.14: He goes to cut down cedars for himself, or he chooses a holm tree or an oak, and he lets it grow strong among the trees of a forest. Or he plants a cedar, and rain causes it to grow tall,
44.15: but it becomes fuel for a man to burn. He takes part of it to warm himself. He lights a fire to bake bread, and then from the rest he makes a god and worships it. He carves an idol and bows down to it.
44.16: Half of it he burns in a fire—over that half he eats meat. He roasts meat and is satisfied. So he is warm and says, “Ah! I am warm. I see the light of the fire.”
44.17: Then from what is left he makes a god to serve as his idol. He bows down to it. He worships it, and he prays to it, “Save me, because you are my god.”
44.18: They are ignorant. They do not understand, because their eyes are plastered shut, and they cannot see. Their hearts are unable to gain insight.
44.19: A person does not take this to heart, so he has no knowledge or understanding to say, “Half of it I burn in the fire, and I bake bread on its coals. I roast meat, and I eat. Should I make the rest of it into a disgusting idol? Should I bow down to a piece of wood?”
44.20: He is like a sheep grazing on ashes. A deceived mind leads him astray. He will not save his life, nor will he say, “Isn’t what I am holding in my right hand a fraud?”
44.21: Remember these things, O Jacob, because you are my servant, Israel. I am forming you to be my servant. You, Israel, you will never be forgotten by me.
44.22: I am blowing away your rebellious deeds like a cloud, and your sins like a mist. Return to me, because I am redeeming you.
44.23:
Shout for joy, you heavens, because of what the Lord is doing.
Make a joyful shout, you depths of the earth.
Burst forth with shouts of joy, you mountains,
you forest and every tree in it,
because the Lord has redeemed Jacob,
and in Israel he will display his beauty.
44.24:
This is what the Lord, your Redeemer,
the Lord who formed you from the womb, says.
    I am the Lord, the one who does all things,
    who stretched out the heavens by myself,
    who hammered out the earth.
    (Who was with me then?)
44.25:
I frustrate the signs of the deceivers
    and make fools of the fortune tellers.
    I overturn the wisdom of the wise
    and turn their knowledge into foolishness.
44.26:
He is the one who fulfills the word of his servants,
who completes the plan announced by his messengers,
who says about Jerusalem, “It will be inhabited,”
and about the cities of Judah, “They will be rebuilt,
and I will raise up their ruins.”
44.27:
He is the one who says to the deep ocean, “Dry up,”
the one who says, “I will dry up your rivers.”
44.28:
He is the one who says about Cyrus, “He is my shepherd,
and he will complete everything I desire.”
He is the one who says about Jerusalem, “It will be rebuilt,”
and who says to the temple, “Your foundations will be laid.”

45.1:
This is what the Lord says to his anointed one,
to Cyrus, whose right hand I have grasped,
    to subdue nations before him
    by stripping kings of their weapons,
    to open doors before him
    so that the gates cannot be shut.
45.2:
I myself will go before you,
    and I will level high mountains.
    I will break bronze doors into pieces,
    and I will cut through iron bars.
45.3:
I will give you treasures hidden in darkness
    and riches concealed in secret places,
    so that you will acknowledge that I am the Lord,
    the one who calls you by name, the God of Israel.
45.4:
For the sake of my servant Jacob,
    for the sake of Israel my chosen one,
    I will call you by your name.
    I will give you an honored name, though you do not know me.
45.5:
I am the Lord, and there is no other.
    Except for me, there is no god.
    I will equip you even though you do not know me,
45.6:
so that people will know from the rising of the sun
            to the place where it sets
        that there is no one except me.
    I am the Lord, and there is no other.
45.7:
I am the one who forms light and creates darkness,
    the one who makes peace and creates disaster.
    I am the Lord, the one who does all these things.
45.8:
Shower down, you heavens, from above,
and let the clouds rain down righteousness.
Let the earth open up,
so that salvation will produce fruit.
Let righteousness sprout up along with it.
I, the Lord, am creating this.
45.9:
Woe to anyone who argues against the potter who formed him.
He is just a potsherd among the broken pieces of pottery on the ground.
Does clay say to its potter, “What are you making?
Your work looks like something made by a potter with no hands”?
45.10:
Woe to anyone who says to his father, “What have you fathered?”
or to a woman, “What are you giving birth to?”
45.11:
This is what the Lord says,
the Holy One of Israel, who formed Israel.
    Do you wish to question me concerning things to come?
    Will you give me orders about my children
    and about the work of my hands?
45.12:
I myself made the earth,
    and I created Adam upon it.
    With my hands I stretched out the heavens,
    and I commanded all their army.
45.13:
I myself will arouse him in righteousness,
and I will make all his roads level for him.
He himself will rebuild my city.
He will set my exiles free—
but not for a price and not for a gift,
says the Lord of Armies.
45.14:
This is what the Lord says.
The wealth of Egypt and the merchandise of Cush
    and those tall Sabeans will cross over to you and become yours.
They will walk behind you and approach you in chains.
They will bow down to you and plead with you and say,
“Yes, God is with you, and there is no other.
There is no other God.”
45.15:
Indeed, you are a God who hides himself.
You are the God of Israel, the Savior.
45.16:
They will be ashamed.
All of them will also be disgraced.
Together they will walk in humiliation—those experts at crafting images.
45.17:
Israel will be saved by the Lord with everlasting salvation.
You will not be ashamed or disgraced for all eternity.
45.18:
This is what the Lord says.
He created the heavens,
He is God!
He formed the earth and made it.
Yes, he established it!
He did not create it to remain empty.
He formed it to be inhabited.
I am the Lord, and there is no other.
45.19:
I did not speak in secret,
or from someplace in a land of darkness.
I did not say to the descendants of Jacob,
“Seek me in the midst of chaos.”
I, the Lord, am speaking in righteousness.
I am declaring what is right.
45.20:
Gather! Come! Draw near together,
you survivors from the nations.
They have no knowledge—
those who are lifting up their idols of wood
and praying to a god that cannot save.
45.21:
Make an announcement and come close.
Let them consult together.
Who made this known ahead of time?
From time past who announced it?
Was it not I, the Lord?
There is no god except me,
a righteous God and Savior.
There is no one except me.
45.22:
Turn to me and be saved, all you ends of the earth,
because I am God,
and there is no other.
45.23:
I have sworn by myself.
From my mouth a righteous word has gone out,
and it will not return unfulfilled.
Indeed, to me every knee will bow,
and every tongue will swear allegiance.
45.24:
“Only in the Lord,” they will say of me,
“Only in the Lord is there true righteousness and strength.”
To him they will come and be ashamed—
all those who are angry at him.
45.25:
In the Lord, all the descendants of Israel will be justified.
They will be praised by him.

46.1:
Bel bows down. Nebo stoops.
Babylon’s idols are a heavy load, carried by animals and cattle.
They are dead weight for the tired animals that carry them.
46.2:
The animals stoop. They bow down together.
They are not able to save their burdensome load.
They go into captivity.
46.3:
Listen to me, O house of Jacob,
all of you who are left from the house of Israel,
you who have been carried from birth,
you who have been lifted up from before you were born.
46.4:
Until your old age, I am he,
    and until you have gray hair, I myself will hold you up.
    I myself made you, and I myself will lift you up.
    I myself will hold you up, and I will rescue you.
46.5:
Whom can you set beside me as if we were equal?
Whom can you compare to me as if we were alike?
46.6:
People pour out gold from a purse
and weigh out silver on a scale.
They hire a smith,
and he makes the metal into a god.
They bow down to it. They even worship it.
46.7:
They lift it up. They carry it on their shoulders.
They set it up in its place, but it just stands there.
It cannot move from its place.
Even when someone cries out to it, it does not answer.
It cannot save him from his distress.
46.8:
Remember this, and stand firm.
You rebels, take this to heart!
46.9:
Remember the former things that took place long ago,
for I am God, and there is no other.
I am God, and there is no one like me.
46.10:
I am the one who announces the final outcome already in the beginning.
I announce ahead of time things that have not yet been done.
I am the one who says, “My plan will stand,
and I will do everything I want to do.”
46.11:
I am the one who calls a bird of prey from the east.
I call the man who fulfills my plan from a faraway land.
Yes, I have spoken. I will certainly bring it to pass.
I have formed a plan, and I will certainly carry it out.
46.12:
Listen to me, you who have stubborn hearts,
you who are far from righteousness.
46.13:
I will bring my righteousness near. It will not be far away.
I will bring my salvation near. It will not be delayed.
I will set up salvation in Zion,
and I will show my splendor to Israel.

47.1:
Go down and sit in the dust, you virgin daughter of Babylon.
Sit on the ground without a throne, daughter of the Chaldeans,
for you will never again be called delicate and pampered.
47.2:
Take millstones and grind meal.
Remove your veil. Strip off your skirt.
Expose your thighs. Wade through rivers.
47.3:
Let your nakedness be exposed.
Let your shame be seen!
I will take vengeance.
I will not spare anyone.
47.4: Our Redeemer—the Lord of Armies is his name—is the Holy One of Israel.
47.5:
Daughter of the Chaldeans, sit silently, and enter into the darkness,
for you will never again be called queen of the kingdoms.
47.6:
I was angry with my people.
I defiled my heritage.
I gave them into your hand.
You showed them no mercy.
Even on the aged you made your yoke very heavy.
47.7:
You said, “I will be a lady forever.”
You did not take these things to heart.
You did not remember how this will turn out.
47.8:
But now hear this, you wanton lover of pleasure,
who sits securely,
who says in her heart,
“I am the one, and there is no one except me.
I will not live as a widow.
I will not experience the loss of children.”
47.9:
But these two things will come upon you in an instant, in one day:
loss of children and widowhood.
They will come to you in full measure
in spite of your many magic spells,
in spite of the great power of your magic charms.
47.10:
You felt secure in your wickedness.
You said, “No one sees me.”
Your wisdom and your knowledge led you astray.
So you said in your heart, “I am the one,
and there is not another one beside me.”
47.11:
But disaster will come upon you.
You do not know when it will come.
Calamity will fall upon you.
You will not be able to atone for it.
A devastating blow that you did not expect will come
    upon you suddenly.
47.12:
Go ahead, stand secure in your magic charms
    and in your many magic spells,
    with which you have been laboring since your youth.
Perhaps you will be able to profit.
Perhaps you will be able to inspire terror.
47.13:
You are worn out by all the advice you receive.
Let them stand up and save you—
those who make charts of the skies to practice astrology,
those who gaze at the stars to obtain omens,
those who predict what will happen to you on each new moon.
47.14:
Look, they are nothing but stubble.
Fire consumes them.
They are not able to save themselves from the power of the flame.
There are no burning coals to warm their food.
There is no firelight to sit in front of.
47.15:
They can do nothing more for you—
those who have worn you out with all their dealings with you
    from your youth.
Each one wanders in his own direction.
There is no one left to save you.

48.1:
Hear this, you house of Jacob,
you who call yourselves by the name of Israel,
who came forth from the waters of Judah,
who swear by the name of the Lord
and invoke the God of Israel,
but not in true righteousness.
48.2:
Yes, they name themselves after the Holy City,
and they lean on the God of Israel—
the Lord of Armies is his name.
48.3:
Things that took place long ago,
I announced before they happened.
From my mouth the announcement went out.
I made these things known.
Then suddenly I acted, and they came about.
48.4:
I did this because I know that you are stubborn.
Your neck is as stiff as iron,
and your forehead is as hard as bronze.
48.5:
I declared this to you long ago.
Before it came about, I announced it to you,
to prevent you from saying, “My false god did it.
My wooden idol and my metal image commanded it.”
48.6:
You heard all this.
Now look at the facts.
Won’t you admit that I am right?
From now on I will also announce new things to you,
hidden things that you never knew.
48.7:
These things are being created right now, not long ago.
You have not heard of them before today,
so you cannot say, “Oh, I already knew that!”
48.8:
No, you have never heard them.
You certainly never knew them.
Your ear was not open, even back then.
Yes, I knew that you would be extremely unfaithful.
You were called a rebel before you were born.
48.9:
For my name’s sake, I am slow to express my anger.
So that I will be praised, I will hold it back from you.
As a result, you are not cut off.
48.10:
You see, I refined you, but not in the same way silver is refined.
I tested you in the furnace of affliction.
48.11:
For my own sake, for my own sake, I will act.
Why should my name be defiled?
My glory I will not give to another.
48.12:
Listen to me, Jacob.
Listen to me, Israel, whom I called.
I am he. I am the first.
I am also the last.
48.13:
It was my hand that laid the foundation of the earth,
and my right hand spread out the heavens.
I summon them and they stand together.
48.14:
Gather together, all of you, and listen.
Who among them announced these things?
The Lord loves him.
He will carry out his desire against Babylon,
and his arm is against Chaldea.
48.15:
I, yes I, have spoken. I am the one who called him.
I have brought him, and his mission will succeed.
48.16:
Come close to me and hear this.
From the beginning, I have not spoken in secret.
From the time it first existed, I was there.
And now God the Lord has sent me with his Spirit.
48.17:
This is what the Lord says, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.
I am the Lord your God,
who teaches you how to succeed,
who leads you in the way you should walk.
48.18:
If only you would have listened carefully to my commandments!
Then your peace would have been like a river,
and your righteousness like the waves of the sea.
48.19:
Your descendants would have been like sand,
and the children from your body like grains of sand.
Their name would never have been cut off or destroyed
    from my presence.
48.20:
Get out of Babylon. Flee from Chaldea.
With a joyful voice declare and announce this.
Send it out to the end of the earth.
Say, “The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob.”
48.21:
They did not suffer thirst in the desolate places
    through which he led them.
He made water flow for them from a rock.
He split open a rock, and water gushed out.
48.22: There is no peace, says the Lord, for the wicked.

49.1:
Listen to me, you coastlands.
Pay attention, you faraway peoples!
The Lord called me from the womb.
When I was inside my mother, he mentioned my name.
49.2:
He made my mouth like a sharpened sword.
He hid me in the shadow of his hand.
He made me a polished arrow.
He concealed me in his quiver.
49.3:
He said to me, “You are my servant Israel,
in whom I will display my glory.”
49.4:
But I said to myself, “I have labored in vain.
I spent my strength and came up empty, with nothing.
Yet a just verdict for me rests with the Lord,
and my reward is with my God.”
49.5:
But now the Lord,
who formed me from the womb to be his servant,
to turn Jacob back to him,
so that Israel might be gathered to him,
so that I will be honored in the eyes of the Lord,
because my God has been my strength—
49.6:
the Lord said:
It is too small a thing that you should just be my servant
    to raise up only the tribes of Jacob
    and to restore the ones I have preserved in Israel,
so I will appoint you to be a light for the nations,
so that my salvation will be known to the end of the earth.
49.7:
This is what the Lord, the Redeemer of Israel, its Holy One,
says to the one deeply despised,
to the one who is detested by the nation,
to the servant of rulers.
    Kings will see and stand up.
    Officials will see and bow down,
    because of the Lord, who is faithful,
    because of the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen you.
49.8:
This is what the Lord says.
In the time of favor, I will answer you.
In the day of salvation, I will help you.
I will guard you,
and I will appoint you to be a covenant for the people,
to re-establish the land,
to redistribute inheritances that are now deserted,
49.9:
to say to the prisoners, “Go forth!”
to those who are in the darkness, “Show yourselves!”
They will graze beside roads,
and they will find pasture on all the barren heights.
49.10:
They will not hunger, and they will not thirst,
and neither scorching wind nor sun will strike them,
because the one who shows them mercy will lead them.
He will guide them beside springs of water.
49.11:
I will make all my mountains into a smooth road,
and my highways will be raised up.
49.12:
Look, people will come from far away.
Look, some will come from the north and the west,
and some from the land of Sinim.
49.13:
Shout for joy, O heavens,
and rejoice, O earth.
Let mountains burst forth with shouts of joy,
because the Lord is comforting his people,
and he is showing mercy to his afflicted ones.
49.14:
But Zion said, “The Lord has abandoned me.
The Lord has forgotten me.”
49.15:
Can a woman forget her nursing child
and not show mercy to the son from her womb?
Even if these women could forget,
I will never forget you.
49.16:
Look, I have inscribed you on the palms of my hands.
Your walls are never out of my sight.
49.17:
Your children are hurrying back.
Those who destroyed and devastated you will depart from you.
49.18:
Lift up your eyes all around and see!
All of them are gathered. They are coming to you.
As surely as I live, declares the Lord,
all of them are like jewelry that you will put on.
You will wear them like a bride.
49.19:
Though your land was wasted and desolate and devastated,
now it will be too small for its inhabitants.
Then those who are swallowing you will be far from you.
49.20:
The children you lost will say this into your ears once again,
“The place is too small for me.
Make room for me so that I can settle there.”
49.21:
Then you will say in your heart,
“Who has given birth to these for me?
I had lost my children and could have no more.
I was exiled and divorced.
So who raised these?
I was left all by myself.
Where did these come from?”
49.22:
This is what God the Lord says.
Look, I will lift up my hand to nations,
and I will raise my signal flag for peoples.
Then they will bring your sons in their embrace,
and your daughters will be carried on their shoulders.
49.23:
Then kings will be your foster fathers,
and their queens will be your nursing mothers.
With their faces to the ground, they will bow down to you.
They will lick the dust at your feet.
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
Those who wait hopefully for me will not be ashamed.
49.24:
Can plunder be taken from a mighty man?
Can captives be rescued from a tyrant?
49.25:
This is what the Lord says.
Even from a mighty man captives can be taken,
and the victims of a tyrant can be rescued.
So I myself will contend with the one who contends with you,
and I myself will save your children.
49.26:
I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh.
They will get drunk on the new wine of their own blood.
So all flesh will know that I am the Lord, your Savior
and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.

50.1:
This is what the Lord says.
So where are the divorce papers of your mother,
whom I sent away?
To which of my creditors did I sell you?
It was because of your guilt that you were sold.
Because of your rebellions, your mother was sent away.
50.2:
When I came, why was no one there?
Why, when I called, was there no one who answered?
Is my arm really too short to redeem?
Do I not have enough power to rescue?
Yes! By my rebuke I can dry up the sea.
I can turn rivers into a wilderness,
so that their fish will stink from having no water,
and they will die of thirst.
50.3:
I can clothe the heavens with blackness,
and I can cover them with sackcloth.
50.4:
The Lord God gave me a tongue like the learned, an instructed tongue,
so I know how to sustain the weary with a word.
He wakes me up morning by morning.
He wakes up my ears so that I listen like the learned.
50.5:
The Lord God opened my ear,
and I myself was not rebellious.
I did not turn back.
50.6:
I submitted my back to those who beat me,
and my cheeks to those who pulled out my beard.
I did not hide my face from disgrace and from spit.
50.7:
The Lord God will help me,
so I will not be disgraced.
Therefore I have made my face hard like flint.
I know that I will not be put to shame.
50.8:
The one who will acquit me is near!
Who can accuse me?
Let us take our stand.
Who can pass judgment on me?
Let him approach me.
50.9:
Look, the Lord God will help me.
Who then can declare me guilty?
Look, all of them will wear out like a garment.
A moth will consume them.
50.10:
Who among you worships the Lord
and listens to the voice of his servant?
Anyone who walks in darkness
and who has no bright light—
let him trust in the name of the Lord,
and let him lean on his God.
50.11:
Watch out, all of you who are lighting fires
    to arm yourselves with flaming arrows.
Go ahead, walk by the light of your fires
and by the flaming arrows you lit!
But from my hand you will receive this:
You will lie down in a place of torment.

51.1:
Listen to me, you people who pursue righteousness,
you people who seek the Lord!
Look confidently to the rock from which you were hewn
and to the quarry from which you were cut.
51.2:
Look confidently to Abraham your father,
and to Sarah, who gave birth to you.
Yes, when I called him, Abraham was only one person,
but I blessed him and multiplied him.
51.3:
The Lord is certain to comfort Zion.
He will comfort all her ruins.
Certainly he will make her wilderness like Eden
and her wasteland like the garden of the Lord.
Joy and gladness will be found in her,
thanksgiving and the sound of music.
51.4:
Pay attention to me, O my people.
My nation, listen to me!
For the law will go out from me,
and I will establish my justice as a light to the peoples.
51.5:
My righteousness is near.
My salvation goes forth,
and my arms will bring justice to the peoples.
The seacoasts will wait for me.
They will have confidence in my arm.
51.6:
Lift up your eyes to the heavens.
Look closely at the earth beneath,
because the heavens will vanish like smoke,
and the earth will wear out like a garment,
and its inhabitants will die like gnats.
But my salvation will remain forever,
and my righteousness will never be abolished.
51.7:
Listen to me, you people who know righteousness,
you people who have my law in your hearts.
Do not fear the insults of men,
and do not be discouraged by their abuse.
51.8:
Because a moth will consume them like a garment,
and its worm will consume them like wool.
But my righteousness will remain forever,
and my salvation will last for all generations.
51.9:
Wake up! Wake up!
Clothe yourself with strength, you arm of the Lord!
Awake as in days of old,
as in generations of long ago.
Was it not you who cut Rahab to pieces,
and who pierced the sea monster?
51.10:
Was it not you who dried up the sea,
    the waters of the great deep,
and who made a road through the depths of the sea
    for the redeemed to cross over?
51.11:
Then those ransomed by the Lord will return.
They will enter Zion with a joyful shout,
and everlasting joy will crown their heads.
Happiness and joy will overtake them.
Sorrow and sighing will flee away.
51.12:
I, even I, am the one who comforts you.
Who are you, Zion, that you fear humans, who die,
or a child of Adam, who passes away like grass?
51.13:
You have forgotten the Lord, your Creator,
who stretches out the heavens,
who makes the earth stand firm.
You tremble continually all day,
because of the rage of the oppressor,
who is preparing to destroy.
But where is the rage of the oppressor now?
51.14:
The prisoner will soon be released.
He will not die and go to the pit,
and he will not lack bread.
51.15:
I am the Lord your God,
who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar.
The Lord of Armies is his name!
51.16:
I have placed my words in your mouth,
and with the shadow of my hand I have covered you—
I, who planted the heavens and laid the foundations of the earth,
I, who say to Zion, “You are my people.”
51.17:
Rouse yourself! Rouse yourself! Get up, Jerusalem!
You have drunk the cup filled with the Lord’s wrath from his hand.
You drank it. You drained the chalice, the cup that makes you stagger.
51.18:
There is no one to guide her from among all the sons she bore.
There is no one to take her hand from among all the sons she raised.
51.19:
Those two things are happening to you.
Who will grieve for you?
Devastation and destruction and famine and sword!
Who will comfort you?
51.20:
